https://t.co/pgdmTs5yf1

Axios reporting that an assassination attempt on Zelensky was prevent by Russian Security Service members that tipped off the Ukrainians.

Pretty remarkable show of courage!

Ukrainian's aren't just fighting for Ukraine.

They are fighting for free democracy around the world.

The outcome of this war will be a playbook or a warning for authoritarians around the world & shape geopolitics for years to come.

This is everyone's fight.

@zachxbt @KembiesNFT Have long been thinking about the importance of non-code audits for this space.

Would be great to see!

RT @KyivPost: The European Parliament has approved Ukraine's application to join the European Union.

A special admission procedure has bee‚Ä¶

@eyliud No, no.

The point is there is no such thing as 'enough' and this is really just a slap in the face.

@eyliud Part of the point is, that no matter what dollar value you put there is that it is never worth it.

A mother being paid more or less for the life of her son, lost in a pointless war, is no better or worse regardless of what economy she spends that money in.

@PlebinMetaverse Of course they won't think about the money.

That's the point.

This is a pointless war of aggression, that is costing innocent lives and paying out a stipend for that loss of live.

This is nothing short of an outrage for these young men and their families.
@alltejuupptaget Yeah, it's way better to have double and be alive.

@aradtski Does that make it better?

Does that mean Russian mothers, who thought their sons were on training missions, should be content when a mad man sent them in on a war of aggression, and paid them out for their loss?
@eyliud You think there is a price your own mother would be happy to be paid, for your death in a war?

Apparently, your dead son, is worth roughly $19k USD.

And that price is dropping because it's in the Ruble.

Wonder how many Russian mothers will think that this is a fair deal, when they thought their sons were training in Belarus? https://t.co/jxmGQsAMWv

Not the first time we've seen Russian forces withdraw or surrender.

The will to fight matters, and we're finding out many Russian infantry have no idea why they are in Ukraine and are unsure why they're shooting at their Slavic neighbors. https://t.co/yVm2XXypVR

RT @adamscochran: 1/6

I feel like it's really worth revisiting the question of the legitimacy of Russia in the UN.

While Russia took over‚Ä¶

PS -- Bonus points, the initial Chinese security council seat was "Republic of China" which is the government of Taiwan, and not the "People's Republic of China" who expelled them and took the seat...soooooo....perhaps another reason for China to learn from Putin's missteps.

6/6

Likely doesn't end up happening, but, worth considering as the body has become an ineffective bundle of red tape and wheel spinning where authoritarians have vetos.

5/6

Seems like a half decent claim to a security council seat for Ukraine and not Russia.

If ever there was the political will for Article 23 reform in the UN and ignoring a Russian veto on grounds of it being 'illegitimate' it'd be now.

4/6

Ukraine has made multiple international court claims about their rights to former USSR property, as it is well recognized as a successor state, and the initial cradle of the earliest Russian Kingdom.

3/6

The earliest Slavic state that eventually led to Russia, also began in Ukraine in English referred to as Kievan Rus' it was Ukraine, Belarus and other parts of North Eastern Europe; and its capital from 882 - 1240 was Kiev.

2/6

That accord recognized Belarus, Kazakhstan, Russia and Ukraine as the legal successors of the state.

The Belovezh Accords, were also only signed by Russia, Ukraine and Belarus.

1/6

I feel like it's really worth revisiting the question of the legitimacy of Russia in the UN.

While Russia took over the USSR seat on the security council, the formal treaty on the matter (the '91 Lisbon Protocol) notes that four states are the successor to the USSR.

So I think its a fair assessment to say you are right on Tsar vs USSR view there!

Probably a Western bias that we mostly saw the USSR as that monolith anyway.

5/5

The lack of a mutually agreeable off-ramp here, will make bringing this to an end tough (unless the Russian people themselves really decide they've had enough)

Maybe we get lucky and Putin agrees to withdraw and just claims, at home, that he won..

4/5

I think the minimum ask that Putin can play off at home as a win, is some sort of political changes in those regions, and then recognition of Crimea as Russia.

But, I doubt Ukraine is interested in that, nor should they be.

3/5

I have to think Ukraine is going to be unwilling to waver on territory like Donestk and Luhansk, but maybe expansions of Minsk agreement protocols that give these people a little more self-sovereign representation within Ukraine?

2/5

He likely wanted a puppet government in Ukraine, but could have even wanted to absorb some of the oblasts (states/regions).

Let's say he is still sensible enough to realize things are bad, what's the ask?

1/5

I have to wonder what the minimum off-ramp here is for Putin.

Unless there is surprising internal regime change, then there has to be an off-ramp where he agrees to a brokered talk.
RT @DeItaone: SWISS GOVERNMENT SAYS ADOPTS EU SANCTIONS ON RUSSIA

@daRealPrabs 4/4

Regardless of the past, the question is today, should we ignore the will of a people to be free? 

A long standing free democracy has been invaded by a super power who has said they have no legitimacy. 

No matter how we got here, we shouldn't turn a blind eye.

@daRealPrabs 3/4

Sorry, what? 

Are you referring to the Revolution of Dignity which was 2013 (while Obama was in office, not Clinton?)

This was Ukraine ousting Yanukovych, who when they voted him out claimed the vote was illegal and tried to ask Russia to help.

@urbitverse @lemiscate @Timccopeland At a certain point, that's what sanctions are.

Usually you attempt to sanction responsible parties first (government) if that fails, sanctions broaden to hit the community in hope it causes their support of war to waver.

3/3

Our world has been more divided than ever these past few years.

But, this moments remind us, that free democracies are at their very best when we stand side-by-side united and unwavering.

We must learn from the history we're writing today.

2/3

We should be proactively learning from what is working in Ukraine and making sure allies around the world, including Taiwan, have the resources they need.

We've got a checkered past, but it doesn't mean we should shy away from the challenges of tomorrow.

1/3

The West will not make the same mistake again.

In 2014, we failed to adequately stand for freedom as Russia took Crimea.

We've learned that governments take action only when citizens raise their voice in outrage. https://t.co/Vvc3MWzkNy

@Bitcoinbuddy121 @rleshner @evankuo I didn‚Äôt say *all* sanctions are good.

I said I believe the are the best political action here to avoid an escalated war in a difficult position.

The situation with Iran is dramatically different than the Russian aggression.

Sanctions are not all good or all bad.

@Bitcoinbuddy121 @rleshner @evankuo They‚Äôve worked countless times in history.

Here‚Äôs a great article that outlines 13 major times:

https://t.co/N6im2PpKmF

And this only covers major political sanctions and not just actions against crimes and individuals.

So sanctions objectively work.
Boss. https://t.co/S19Rciid3h

Huge shift, and once again a government choosing to take a rare and unprecedented action after civilians raised their voice in protest.

Government responses comes when civilians in the West make clear we want to support Ukraine in the face of tyranny. https://t.co/LV4bioFU48

@LefterisJP Thanks for making your voice heard on this one. 

It's actions like this, that have let the German government know they can take strong actions on sanctions and stand with their NATO allies despite the hardships it may cause!

P.S. - Ukrainians also know how to eat. Their varenyky (pierogi) are kickass.

So if you‚Äôve felt the bar is too high and you do nothing else, you can at least eat some damn dumplings and support your local Ukrainian business!

5/5

It‚Äôs a small thing, but sometimes when millions of us come together and do small things, it can make a big difference.

4/5

Take sometime to order Ukrainian food, or reach out to the Ukrainian association in your country/province or state, learn what businesses are Ukrainian owned near you that you can switch your buying towards.

3/5

In a war, we can feel so small, like there isn‚Äôt anything we can really do to get aid to people.

No one will better know how to get support to their friends and families in need, than their own community.

2/5

While at least 400,000 Ukrainians are already displaced and hard to get aid to, it is the Ukrainian community that will end up supporting their brothers, sisters, mothers, fathers and friends for years to come.

Let‚Äôs make sure they have the funds to do so!

1/5

If you‚Äôre looking for some small way to help Ukrainians, consider buying from local Ukrainian owned businesses and restaurants and your local Ukrainian association.

In the West, we sadly far too often forget and overlook the humanitarian issue here,

3/3

It‚Äôs critical to call out disinformation. Even if we aren‚Äôt an expert in these things we can research, compare and raise critical questions, so that these claims aren‚Äôt taken as fact.

In Ukraine, this is a fight for territory, in the West it‚Äôs a fight for hearts and minds.

2/3 

The supposed video that they are using by the way is an upward/outward explosion and a pluming fire. That‚Äôs not munitions raining down. Looks like something explosive on fire (like an ammo depot?)

1/3

None of which seems plausible, or has any evidence in the most watched and recorded war in history.

White phosphorus distinctly scars the sky.

Pretty huge.

Germany has long had, a very popular policy, of not exporting lethal weapons to conflict regions.

It‚Äôs a pretty big political shift for them, that likely means we see them take a harder stance on other things like sanctions as well. https://t.co/jEyylNxCk2

@Cryptonoon121 As noted in another comment, that‚Äôs not raw spend, this number includes the price of sanctions, and the loss on the Russian economy from things like stock market decline, etc.

It‚Äôs not the usual military spend number so it seems inflated, but is an overall economic cost.

@sofakingtilted It's also worth noting, that wars do seem to be a higher price per day to start due to expensive munitions spent, versus just using infantry in later portions.

But it looks like most of this would consist of Russian economic decline.

@sofakingtilted Great question, and the tweet lacks some clarity, that estimate is not the raw spend, but the spend + the economic cost (such as the decline in the Russian stock market etc)

So its price per day will be inflated at first and average lower over time.

20/20

We can expect increased Russian propaganda over the coming days, in Ukraine, at home, and around the world.

But make no mistake, each day this drags on, unravels the Russian fa√ßade of strength and power.

Each day it drags on, we come closer to David repelling Goliath.

19/20

Had Putin taken Kyiv swiftly, the loss would have been overwhelming, but as it stands, Kyiv has given up a fight that no one expected.

If it falls, the city becomes a martyr of this defense and likely galvanizes an insurgency resistance that will fight tooth and nail.

18/20

The cracks for Russia's military, and an authoritarians stranglehold on the nation have started to show.

Even if Kyiv falls in the days to come, I believe we are past the point where Ukrainians will see that as a moment to recede.

17/20

Those kinds of claims are tough to validate, but the NATO and allied intelligence apparatus has done an amazing job so far in releasing public information to undercut Russia's attacks, and so it certainly seems likely that this information could be on the right track.

16/20

Some intelligence reports have gone as far as to suggest that after 10-12 days of fighting we would start to see major gaps in Russian supply lines, and their ability to continue to shell key locations.
